algorithm_technique: Digit DP with bitmasks and combinatorics
Digit DP with bitmasks and permutations
problem_summary_simple: Count numbers with unique digits in a given range [a, b].
problem_summary_technical: Uses digit DP with bitmasks to count numbers with unique digits up to a limit, then applies inclusion-exclusion.
key_insights: The problem is solved by calculating count(b+1) - count(a), where count(x) is the number of unique-digit numbers less than x.
Digit DP with bitmasks is used to efficiently count numbers with unique digits up to a given number.
The bitmask tracks used digits, and combinatorics (permutations) helps count possibilities for remaining digits.
The problem is solved by calculating count(b+1) - count(a), where count(x) is the number of unique-digit numbers less than x.
Digit DP with bitmasks and permutations is used to count numbers with unique digits up to a given number.
The logic involves iterating through digits of the number and using permutations to count valid combinations.
A straightforward approach is to iterate through each number in the range [a, b].
For each number, check if its digits are unique using a bitmask or a set.
Sum up the counts of numbers with unique digits.
A straightforward approach is to iterate through each number in the range [a, b].
For each number, convert it to a string and check if the length of the string is equal to the length of the set of its characters.
Sum up the counts of numbers with unique digits.
